labels_to_summaries.C0:
• Council is considering Resolution 2025-1681 to authorize a $52,962.24 payment to the Pennsylvania Municipal League for a one-year membership subscription

• The resolution was presented by Councilman Kihari-Mosley and referred to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for review

• If approved, the Mayor would be authorized to issue the payment warrant, with the City Controller countersigning it

• The payment would come from the city's budget account 11101.102200.53.53101.2025

• The Pennsylvania Municipal League provides services and resources to municipal governments across the state
labels_to_summaries.G0:
- Pittsburgh City Council has introduced a resolution to pay up to $52,962.24 for the city's one-year subscription to the Pennsylvania Municipal League.
- The legislation, presented by Councilman Kihari-Mosley, would authorize the Mayor and City Controller to make the payment.
- The resolution has been referred to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for review before a final vote.
labels_to_summaries.O0:
- The City Council approved Resolution 2025-1681 to pay the Pennsylvania Municipal League for a one-year subscription.  
- The payment amount is up to $52,962.24.  
- The Mayor is authorized to issue the payment warrant, and the City Controller will countersign it.  
- Funds will be charged to account 11101.102200.53.53101.2025.  
- Councilman Kihari-Mosley presented the resolution during the meeting.
labels_to_summaries.C1:
• Pittsburgh City Council introduced a resolution to pay $72,500 in overdue fees to the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission (PUC)

• The debt comes from unpaid bills for 811 damage prevention calls, which help locate underground utilities before digging

• The resolution authorizes the Mayor to issue a warrant for the full $72,500 payment to settle the city's delinquent account

• The measure was read and referred to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for further review

• 811 calls are required by law before construction or excavation work to prevent damage to gas, electric, water, and other utility lines
labels_to_summaries.G1:
- City Council introduced a resolution to pay $72,500 to the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission (PUC).
- The payment covers the city's overdue debts for "811 damage prevention calls," which are part of the state's "Call Before You Dig" program.
- If passed, Resolution 2025-1682 will authorize the Mayor and City Controller to issue the payment warrant.
- The resolution has been sent to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for review before a final council vote.
labels_to_summaries.O1:
- The City Council approved Resolution 2025-1682 to pay $72,500 to the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission (PUC).  
- This payment covers delinquent debts owed by the City for 811 damage prevention calls.  
- The Mayor is authorized to issue the warrant, and the City Controller will countersign it.  
- Funds will be drawn from the City’s budget account 11101.600000.53.53101.2025.  
- The resolution was referred to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for further review.
labels_to_summaries.C2:
• Council is repealing Resolution 366 from 2019, which allowed the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) to take over city-owned property in the 15th Ward at no cost to the city

• The property is located at Block 56-B, Lot 345 in Council District 5

• The URA requested the repeal, meaning they want to give up control of the property

• Resolution 2025-1683 was introduced and sent to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for review

• If approved, the URA will relinquish its interest in the property and it will return to city control
labels_to_summaries.G2:
- The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is asking the City Council to cancel a previously approved plan for it to take over a city-owned property.
- The property is located in the 15th Ward (Council District 5) and is identified as Block 56-B, Lot 345.
- In 2019, the City Council passed a resolution allowing the URA to acquire the property from the city at no cost.
- A new resolution has been introduced to repeal the 2019 decision, which would officially stop the property transfer.
- The new legislation has been sent to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for further review.
labels_to_summaries.O2:
- The City Council repealed Resolution 366 of 2019, which had authorized the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) of Pittsburgh to acquire the City’s rights to a publicly owned property in the 15th Ward (Block 56-B, Lot 345, Council District 5) at no cost to the City.  
- The repeal means the URA will no longer acquire or hold any interest in this property.  
- This action was formalized through Resolution 2025-1683 and referred to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs.  
- The repeal is effective retroactively from June 14, 2019, the original effective date of the prior resolution.
labels_to_summaries.C3:
• Council approved a resolution allowing the Urban Redevelopment Authority to sell two vacant lots in the Hill District to the Pittsburgh Land Bank for $16,290 plus costs

• The properties are located on Erin Street in Council District 6 (Block 10-J, Lots 259 and 260) in the 5th Ward

• The lots are part of the Greater Hill District Redevelopment Area, a designated zone for neighborhood improvement

• The sale requires no cost to the City of Pittsburgh

• The resolution was read and referred to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for further review

• This transaction supports the Land Bank's mission to acquire and redevelop vacant properties in the city
labels_to_summaries.G3:
- The City Council is reviewing a resolution to approve the sale of two lots from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) to The Pittsburgh Land Bank.
- The properties are located on Erin Street in the Hill District (5th Ward) and are identified as Block 10-J, Lots 259 and 260.
- According to the official legislation, the sale price for the two lots is $16,290 plus costs.
- The council agenda notes the transaction comes at "no cost to the City," as the City is not the purchaser.
- The resolution has been referred to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for further review.
labels_to_summaries.O3:
- The City Council approved Resolution 2025-1684 to authorize a land sale contract between the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) of Pittsburgh and the Pittsburgh Land Bank.  
- The sale involves Block 10-J, Lots 259 and 260, located in the 5th Ward on Erin Street, within Council District 6.  
- The contract price for the property is $16,290 plus additional costs.  
- The property is part of the Greater Hill District Redevelopment Area.  
- The sale is at no cost to the City of Pittsburgh, meaning the City will not incur expenses from this transaction.  
- Council believes the sale supports the City's redevelopment goals and is in the public interest.
labels_to_summaries.C4:
• Council approved the sale of city-owned land on Island Avenue to Island Avenue Holdings, LLC for $3,600 plus costs

• The property is located at Block 21-D, Lot 42-A in the 27th Ward (Council District 2)

• The Urban Redevelopment Authority of Pittsburgh will handle the sale contract

• The land was originally purchased using money from the Industrial Land Reserve Fund

• The resolution was read and sent to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for review

• Council determined the sale is in the best interest of the city
labels_to_summaries.G4:
- The Pittsburgh City Council is considering a proposal from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) to sell a vacant lot on Island Avenue.
- The property, located in Council District 2, would be sold to a private company named Island Avenue Holdings, LLC.
- The official legislation sets the sale price at $3,600, plus any additional costs related to the sale.
- Although the agenda described the sale as having “no cost to the City,” this refers to the fact that the city is not spending any money on the transaction.
- As a first step, the council has referred the proposal to its Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for further review before a final vote is taken.
labels_to_summaries.O4:
- The City Council approved Resolution 2025-1685 to sell land located at Block 21-D, Lot 42-A in the 27th Ward on Island Avenue to Island Avenue Holdings, LLC.  
- The sale price is $3,600 plus additional costs, with no cost to the City.  
- The property was originally purchased using the Industrial Land Reserve Fund.  
- The Urban Redevelopment Authority of Pittsburgh requested authorization to execute the contract for this sale.  
- Council agreed the sale is in the best interest of the City and gave its official approval.
labels_to_summaries.C5:
• Council approved the sale of a property on North Aiken Avenue in the 11th Ward from the Urban Redevelopment Authority to the Pittsburgh Land Bank for $48,500 plus costs

• The property is located at Block 83-A, Lot 48 in Council District 9

• The land was originally purchased using the city's Residential Land Reserve Fund

• While the sale price is $48,500, there is no cost to the city for this transaction

• The resolution was read and referred to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for further review

• Council determined the sale is in the best interest of the city
labels_to_summaries.G5:
- City Council is reviewing a resolution to approve the sale of a property from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) to The Pittsburgh Land Bank.
- The sale price for the property is $48,500 plus costs.
- The property is a single lot located on North Aiken Avenue in the 11th Ward.
- According to the resolution, the sale will be at "no cost to the City."
- The URA originally bought the property using money from the Residential Land Reserve Fund.
- The legislation (Resolution 2025-1686) has been sent to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for review.
labels_to_summaries.O5:
- The City Council approved Resolution 2025-1686 to sell Block 83-A, Lot 48 on North Aiken Avenue in the 11th Ward (Council District 9) to the Pittsburgh Land Bank.  
- The sale price is $48,500 plus additional costs, with no cost to the City itself.  
- The property was purchased using the Residential Land Reserve Fund.  
- The contract was requested by the Urban Redevelopment Authority of Pittsburgh and is considered in the best interest of the city.  
- The resolution was read and referred to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs for further consideration.
labels_to_summaries.C6:
• City Council amended a 2024 resolution that originally sought $461,856 from Pennsylvania's Multimodal Transportation Fund for the Penn Avenue lighting project

• The grant amount was reduced to $450,000 — a decrease of $11,856 from the original request

• The project is part of the AI Corridor Penn Avenue Lighting initiative

• Council authorized the Mayor, Budget Director, and Mobility and Infrastructure Director to enter into agreements with the state for the reduced grant amount

• Officials are authorized to spend up to $450,000 from the grant through regular city procurement processes

• Grant money will be deposited into a specific city trust fund account

• The resolution was presented by Councilwoman Barbara Warwick and referred to the Public Works and Infrastructure Committee
labels_to_summaries.G6:
- City Council introduced legislation to officially accept a $450,000 state grant for the "AI Corridor Penn Avenue Lighting Project."
- The grant comes from the Pennsylvania Department of Economic Development's Multimodal Transportation Fund.
- The city originally applied for a larger amount, $461,856, but the final award was reduced.
- If passed, the resolution will allow the Mayor's office and other city departments to sign the official agreement and spend the funds.
- The legislation has been sent to the Committee on Public Works and Infrastructure for further review.
labels_to_summaries.O6:
- The City Council approved amending Resolution No. 803 of 2024 to reduce the Penn Avenue Lighting project grant from $461,856 to $450,000.  
- The amendment authorizes the Mayor, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and the Director of the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure to accept the reduced grant amount.  
- These officials are also authorized to enter into agreements with the Pennsylvania Department of Economic Development’s Multimodal Transportation Fund for the project.  
- All expenditures related to the grant are capped at $450,000 and must follow regular procurement processes.  
- Grant funds will be deposited into the Grants Trust Fund account 6029400514.455247.00 and charged to job number 6029400514.
labels_to_summaries.C7:
• City Council referred a resolution to the Public Works and Infrastructure Committee to increase funding for Fort Pitt Park design work

• The contract with Pashek + MTR would increase by $115,170, bringing the total cost from $300,000 to $415,170

• The additional money is needed because the project now includes Phase 2 scope of services beyond the original Phase 1 improvements

• Pashek + MTR was originally selected through a competitive bidding process that started in July 2023

• The funding comes from two different job numbers: $300,000 from the original budget and $115,170 from a new budget line

• The contract extension covers one year of work
labels_to_summaries.G7:
- City council is considering adding $115,170 to the contract for designing improvements at Fort Pitt Park.
- The money would go to the design firm Pashek + MTR.
- This increase is needed because the project's scope has grown to include a second phase of work.
- The original contract was for $300,000 and only covered the design for Phase 1.
- If approved, the new total cost for designing both Phase 1 and Phase 2 would be $415,170.
- The proposed resolution has been sent to the Committee on Public Works and Infrastructure for review before a final vote.
labels_to_summaries.O7:
- City Council approved an increase of $115,170 to the original $300,000 budget for Pashek + MTR’s professional design services for Fort Pitt Park Phase 1 improvements.  
- The total authorized cost is now $415,170, covering both Phase 1 and additional Phase 2 design services.  
- The agreement will last one year and is chargeable to two job numbers: $300,000 to job 4550000122 and $115,170 to job 4550020824.  
- The Mayor and Director of Public Works are authorized to enter into or amend agreements with Pashek + MTR, subject to City Solicitor approval.  
- The increase reflects added scope and costs related to Phase 2 of the project.
labels_to_summaries.C8:
• Council Member Wilson introduced Resolution 2025-1691 to move $33,292 within the 2025 city budget

• The money will be transferred from City Council Districts' regular salary and wage accounts to employee benefits

• The funds are specifically designated for tuition reimbursement programs for council district employees

• The resolution was read and referred to the Committee on Finance and Law for review

• This is a budget transfer within existing funds, not new spending
labels_to_summaries.G8:
- City Council introduced a resolution to transfer $33,292 to pay for tuition reimbursement for council staff.
- The legislation, sponsored by Council Member Bobby Wilson, would move the funds from the City Council’s 2025 salary budget to its employee benefits budget.
- The proposed transfer, Resolution 2025-1691, was referred to the Committee on Finance and Law for further review.
labels_to_summaries.O8:
- The City Council approved Resolution 2025-1691 to transfer $33,292 within the 2025 Operating Budget.  
- Funds were moved from City Council Districts Salaries & Wages, Regular to City Council Districts Employee Benefits.  
- The transfer is specifically for tuition reimbursement purposes for City Council district employees.  
- Councilman Bobby Wilson sponsored and presented the resolution during the meeting.  
- The Controller and Office of Management and Budget are authorized to carry out the transfer.
labels_to_summaries.C9:
• City Council accepted a $500 donation from the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust to buy smoke detectors for Pittsburgh residents

• The donation will go to the Department of Public Safety, which will distribute the smoke detectors to city residents

• Jake Pawlak, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, presented the donation to council

• Council voted to read, receive, and file the communication, officially accepting the donation

• The donation amount will not exceed $500
labels_to_summaries.G9:
- The City Council officially accepted a $500 donation from the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust.
- The donation was submitted by the Office of Management and Budget on behalf of the Department of Public Safety.
- The funds will be used by the Department of Public Safety to purchase smoke detectors, which will then be given to city residents.
labels_to_summaries.O9:
- The City received a $500 donation from the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust.
- The donation is designated for the Department of Public Safety to purchase smoke detectors.
- These smoke detectors will be distributed to City residents to enhance fire safety.
- The communication was submitted by Jake Pawlak, Director of the Office of Management and Budget.
- The City Council formally received and filed the donation without objection.
labels_to_summaries.M10:
- Open-ended professional services contracts allow vendors to provide on-call professional services for work orders estimated to cost $100,000 or less.
- The program’s goal is to enable City departments to contract services on a rolling basis without seeking Council approval for each request.
- Services include architecture, interior design, and historic consulting, among others.
- New vendors will be added to the program on a rolling basis, but any new additions will require Council approval.
- Councilperson Charland expressed concern that the “fairly self-governing” system of distributing work could lead departments to overlook minority contractors.
labels_to_summaries.C10:
• Pittsburgh City Council unanimously approved 56 additional professional services contracts for city departments, expanding the total from 36 to 92 contracts.

• Each contract can be worth up to $1.5 million per year for a three-year term, allowing departments to hire outside professionals on an as-needed basis.

• Individual work orders under these contracts cannot exceed $500,000 in value.

• The contracts cover various professional services needed by different city departments, with funding identified when specific work orders are issued.

• If funding for any work order hasn't been previously set aside, City Council will need to approve additional funding through separate action.

• The vote was 8-0 in favor, with one council member absent.

• This amendment builds on Resolution 564 from 2024, which originally authorized the first 36 contracts under the same terms.
labels_to_summaries.G10:
- The City Council unanimously approved adding 56 new contracts for on-call professional services, bringing the total number of agreements to 92.
- These contracts allow various city departments to hire vendors for professional services as needed over a three-year term.
- Each of the 92 agreements has an annual spending cap of $1,500,000.
- While contracts can be large, any single work order for a specific project is limited to a maximum of $500,000.
- The resolution passed with an 8-0 vote and no discussion from council members.
labels_to_summaries.O10:
- The City Council approved a resolution to add 56 new open-end professional services agreements with multiple vendors, increasing the total from 36 to 92 agreements.  
- Each agreement is for a three-year term and capped at $1,500,000 annually.  
- These agreements allow the city’s departments to request professional services on an as-needed, on-call basis.  
- Individual work orders under these agreements cannot exceed $500,000 in value.  
- Funding for work orders will be identified and appropriated through future City Council actions as needed.  
- The resolution passed unanimously with 8 votes in favor and 1 member absent.
labels_to_summaries.C11:
• City Council unanimously approved spending $13,499.98 to buy a diagnostic tool for repairing city vehicles

• The Mac Scan tool will be purchased from Canon Tools and used by the Department of Public Works (DPW)

• The purchase will be paid over one year from the city's budget

• Eight council members voted yes, with one member absent from the meeting

• The diagnostic tool will help city workers repair and maintain DPW vehicles more effectively
labels_to_summaries.G11:
- The City Council approved the purchase of a new diagnostic tool for the Department of Public Works (DPW).
- The "Mac Scan tool" will be used to help repair city-owned vehicles.
- The council authorized a payment of exactly $13,499.98 to the vendor, Canon Tools, for the equipment.
- The resolution passed with a final, unanimous vote of 8-0.
labels_to_summaries.O11:
- The City Council approved a resolution to purchase one Mac Scan tool for repairing Department of Public Works (DPW) vehicles.  
- The total cost of the tool is $13,499.98, to be paid over one year.  
- The Mayor is authorized to issue, and the City Controller to countersign, a warrant in favor of Canon Tools for this purchase.  
- Funding for the purchase will come from account 4000280300.56401.2025.  
- The resolution passed unanimously with 8 votes in favor, 0 against, and 1 member absent.
labels_to_summaries.M12:
- A bill covering $35k in expenses for portable bathrooms led to a discussion about the number of broken permanent public restrooms in the city’s parks.
- Director Hornstein of the Department of Public Works did not have an exact count of closed public restrooms to share with Council.

  - The actual repairs and maintenance, which will likely be significant given how long some have been closed.
  - A program to maintain the restrooms once they are reopened.
- The city spent $219,000 on portable restrooms in parks that lack functioning permanent public restrooms.
- Council members agreed that there should be a plan to begin addressing this long-standing issue.

labels_to_summaries.C18:
• City Council approved accepting $316,367 from a legal settlement involving the Finland Street Pedestrian Bridge

• The settlement resolves litigation filed in Allegheny County Court of Common Pleas against a company that damaged the bridge so severely it had to be removed

• The bridge previously connected areas across Bigelow Boulevard, providing safe pedestrian crossing between neighborhoods

• Councilman Gross expressed safety concerns about the loss of pedestrian infrastructure, noting people now must cross at less safe locations to reach bus stops

• Current crossing options are limited to the Bloomfield Bridge and Heron Avenue, with Heron Avenue described as not very safe

• The state previously closed an underpass at Heron Avenue without notifying the city, further reducing safe crossing options

• Councilman Gross requested the administration conduct a pedestrian safety audit and provide suggestions for improvements

• The settlement funds will be deposited into city account 6031010225.44109.00

• Council gave the resolution an affirmative recommendation to move forward
labels_to_summaries.G18:
- A City Council committee recommended accepting a $316,367 legal settlement for the Finland Street Pedestrian Bridge.
- The settlement comes from a company that damaged the bridge so severely that it had to be torn down.
- The bridge used to cross over Bigelow Boulevard, and its removal has created significant safety concerns for people walking in the area.
- A councilmember noted that residents, including those trying to reach bus stops, now have to use crossings further away at the Bloomfield Bridge or Heron Avenue.
- As part of the discussion, the council member requested that the city's Department of Mobility and Infrastructure conduct a pedestrian safety study on that section of Bigelow Boulevard.
labels_to_summaries.O18:
- City Council approved a $316,367 settlement in full and final resolution of litigation related to the Finland Street Pedestrian Bridge.
- The bridge was severely damaged and had to be removed after an incident involving a company, leading to the lawsuit.
- Councilman Gross expressed support for the settlement but raised concerns about pedestrian safety on Bigelow Boulevard, where the bridge once provided a key crossing.
- He requested a pedestrian safety audit from Delmay to explore improvements, noting current crossings at the Bloomfield Bridge and Heron Avenue are insufficient and sometimes unsafe.
- The closure of a former underpass at Heron Avenue by the state, without city notification, adds to safety challenges.
- The settlement funds will be deposited into the city’s designated account as authorized by the resolution.
labels_to_summaries.C19:
• Council approved a three-year agreement with USI Insurance Services to handle all city insurance brokerage services with two optional one-year extensions

• The agreement costs the city nothing directly because insurance brokers are paid commissions by insurance companies, not by the city

• USI will replace the city's previous broker whose contract expired

• The city carries multiple types of insurance including:
  - Property coverage for buildings
  - Boat insurance
  - Equipment insurance for cameras on non-city property
  - Cybersecurity insurance
  - Errors and omissions insurance for EMS
  - Crime insurance for elected officials

• New insurance policies will take effect May 1

• The city will pay insurance premiums directly to carriers using budget funds already approved by Council

• One council member expressed concern about approving both the broker agreement and future insurance policies in the same resolution, preferring separate approvals for transparency
labels_to_summaries.G19:
- A City Council committee recommended approving a contract with USI Insurance Services to act as the city's new insurance broker.
- The city is switching brokers after its previous contract expired and USI was selected through a competitive bidding process.
- The agreement is "no-cost" to the city, as the broker is paid a commission by the insurance carriers, not by the city directly. The city still pays for the actual insurance policies.
- The contract is for a three-year term, with two one-year options to extend. New policies arranged by the broker are expected to take effect on May 1.
- The broker will handle all of the city's insurance needs, which include property, cybersecurity, and errors and emissions insurance for EMS.
- One council member expressed concern that this agreement could bypass future council votes on individual insurance policies, but the legislation was still recommended to move forward.
labels_to_summaries.O19:
- City Council approved a no-cost, three-year agreement with USI Insurance Services to provide insurance brokerage for all necessary policy types, with two one-year extension options.  
- The contract involves no direct payment to USI; instead, insurance carriers pay commissions to the broker, which is standard industry practice.  
- The City will continue to pay for insurance policies themselves, such as property, boat, cybersecurity, EMS errors and omissions, and crime insurance for officials, from existing budget lines.  
- This agreement follows a recent RFP process and replaces the previous broker whose contract expired.  
- New insurance policies procured under this agreement will take effect starting May 1.  
- Council members expressed some concerns about the broad scope of the agreement and the embedded approval of resulting policies but were assured that policy payments are budgeted and that transparency will be maintained.
labels_to_summaries.C20:

labels_to_summaries.O20:

labels_to_summaries.M22:
- The Police Department is requesting approval to spend $32K from a State grant on a new recruitment video to be developed by Kicker, Inc.
- Videos are expected to include “exciting and proud images of Pittsburgh Police Officers at work in various positions, including Patrol, K-9 Unit, Investigators, SWAT, Motorcycle Unit, Mounted Patrol, River Patrol, Special Victims Unit, Narcotics/Vice, and Computer Crimes Unit” as well as iconic Pittsburgh imagery.
- Council noted the need for new recruitment efforts and was pleased to hear that the number of people taking the civil service exam has begun to increase. They hope the videos are as successful as they have been in other cities.
- The videos will primarily be used across social media platforms and YouTube.
labels_to_summaries.C22:
• Council approved a $32,750 contract with Kicker, Inc. to create police recruitment videos over one year

• The videos will include conceptualization, scripting, and production planning to help attract new police officers

• All costs will be paid from a $315,000 grant from PCCD (Pennsylvania Commission on Crime and Delinquency), so no city funds are used

• Kicker was selected through a national RFP process and has experience making police recruitment videos for other cities

• The company will produce a main recruitment video plus shorter clips for social media, YouTube, and traditional media

• Police will handle marketing and distribution internally through their public information officers and social media staff

• Recent recruitment efforts are showing progress - 170 people signed up for last month's civil service exam with 90 showing up, more than double previous months

• Pittsburgh currently has two full-time recruitment officers and police academy classes scheduled for June and November

• The videos will be filmed in Pittsburgh using local police officers as volunteers

• Council members requested to see the final video product once completed in a few months

• The measure received affirmative recommendation from the Public Safety Committee
labels_to_summaries.G22:
*   The City Council’s Public Safety and Wellness Committee recommended spending up to $32,750 to hire an outside company, Kicker, Inc., to create police recruitment videos.
*   The contract will be paid for using part of a larger, pre-existing state grant of roughly $315,000 that was awarded to the city to help with recruitment efforts.
*   The company, which has made similar videos for other cities, will produce a main video and shorter clips for social media. The goal is to attract more applicants for the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police.
*   Police officials noted that this is part of a larger effort to boost hiring, which seems to be working. The number of people showing up for the police entry exam has recently more than doubled compared to previous months.
*   The proposal now moves to the full City Council for a final vote.
labels_to_summaries.O22:
- The City Council approved a $32,750 contract with Kicker, Inc. to produce a police recruitment video over one year.  
- The video production includes conceptualization, scripting, and planning to help boost police recruitment efforts.  
- Funding comes from a Public Safety grant account, part of a larger $315,000 recruitment grant received about a year ago.  
- Kicker, Inc. was selected through a national Request for Proposal (RFP) process based on price and qualifications.  
- The video will be used on social media, YouTube, and traditional media to promote police careers but does not include marketing or distribution services.  
- Recruitment efforts are showing early signs of success, with recent civil service exam sign-ups doubling compared to previous months.  
- Council members expressed support and interest in seeing the final video once completed, expected in a few months.  
- The contract and project are a new approach for the Police Bureau, aiming to creatively address ongoing recruitment challenges.
labels_to_summaries.C23:
• Council's Public Works Committee recommended accepting a significantly reduced state grant for the Smallman Street Complete Street Project

• The city originally applied for $2.28 million from Pennsylvania's Multimodal Transportation Fund but will now receive only $250,000

• The original proposal included a $117,100 local match from the 2024 Capital Budget for a total project cost of $2.4 million

• The reduced grant amount represents about 89% less funding than initially requested

• The Smallman Street Complete Street Project aims to improve transportation infrastructure and safety

• The resolution authorizes the Mayor, Budget Director, and Mobility and Infrastructure Director to enter into agreements with the Pennsylvania Department of Economic Development

• Grant funds will be deposited into the city's Grants Trust Fund and cannot exceed $250,000 in expenditures

• The committee gave an affirmative recommendation, moving the resolution forward in the approval process
labels_to_summaries.G23:

labels_to_summaries.O23:
- The City Council approved an amendment to Resolution No. 615 of 2024 for the Smallman Street Complete Street Project grant.

labels_to_summaries.C24:

labels_to_summaries.O24:

- The additional funds will support the Right of Way and Construction phases of the project, with specific allocations from Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) funds and City bonds across 2024 and 2025 budget years.

labels_to_summaries.G25:
- City Council approved an additional $317,588 for the South Negley Avenue Bridge project in a supplemental agreement with the engineering firm WSP USA, Inc.
- This increase brings the total cost of the agreement to $1,188,409.

labels_to_summaries.O25:
- City Council approved a supplemental agreement with WSP USA, Inc. for the South Negley Avenue Bridge project.

labels_to_summaries.M26:
- The expansion will encompass 14 acres west along Penn Avenue in the Larimer and East Liberty neighborhoods.
- The standout initiative is the Build 100 program, which calls for Walnut Capital to contribute $6 million and commit to raising another $19 million toward creating 100 affordable homes for purchase.
- This work is the product of a Community Benefits Agreement between the Larimer Consensus Group, the Village Collaborative, and Walnut Capital.
- Council sent the proposed amendments to the Planning Commission on July 6 and July 12, 2023, and received the Commission’s report and recommendation for both on January 24, 2025.
- The 4/2 vote allows for two bills—one delineating new block and lot numbers and the other detailing building code and other requirements within the subdistrict—to proceed to a public hearing.
labels_to_summaries.C26:
• Council approved amended zoning changes to expand the Bakery Square development in East Liberty, moving the proposal forward to a public hearing

• The ordinance changes zoning designations for multiple properties:
  - Highway Commercial to SP-9/Bakery Square District near Penn Avenue and East Liberty Boulevard
  - Urban Industrial to SP-9/Bakery Square District in the 12th Ward
  - Highway Commercial to Urban Industrial near the Norfolk Southern Rail line

• The expansion includes a community benefits agreement negotiated over several years between neighborhood groups, the developer, and city officials

• Affordable housing requirements were secured through negotiations:
  - Off-site: 100 affordable homes for purchase at 80% Area Median Income (AMI) in Larimer and potentially other East End neighborhoods
  - On-site: 10% affordable rental units at 50% AMI and 5% at 80-120% AMI

• The on-site affordable housing component was added through recent negotiations between the mayor's office and Council, beyond the original community benefits agreement

• Council praised the Larimer Consensus Group and Village Collaborative for their multi-year advocacy work on the project

• A public hearing will be held to allow community input before final approval
labels_to_summaries.G26:
- A plan to rezone several parcels of land near Bakery Square is moving forward after a City Council vote. The changes would expand the SP-9/Bakery Square special zoning district.

- The rezoning is linked to a Community Benefits Agreement that includes a program to build 100 affordable homes for purchase in nearby neighborhoods like Larmer. These homes will be for residents earning 80% of the area median income (AMI).

- Recent negotiations also added an on-site affordable housing requirement for the new development. 10% of the new rental units must be affordable:
    - 5% of units for residents at or below 50% AMI.
    - 5% of units for residents between 80% and 120% AMI.

- Council voted to approve the updated plan and will now schedule a public hearing for community feedback before taking a final vote.
labels_to_summaries.O26:
- Council amended Ordinance 2023-1723 to change zoning in the Bakery Square area, shifting properties between Highway Commercial (HC), Urban Industrial (UI), and SP-9/Bakery Square Districts in the 11th and 12th Wards.  
- The zoning changes affect multiple specific parcels bounded by Penn Avenue, East Liberty Boulevard, the East Busway, and the Norfolk Southern Rail line.  
- This amendment is part of a multi-year process involving neighborhood groups, developers, and previous council leadership, aiming to support community benefits.  
- Key community benefits include the Build 100 program, which will create 100 affordable homes for purchase in East Liberty and nearby neighborhoods.  
- The ordinance also includes negotiated on-site affordable rental housing: 10 units at 50% Area Median Income (AMI) and 5 units between 80% and 120% AMI.  
- The bills were amended by substitution and then held for a cablecast public hearing to allow for further public discussion.  
- Councilmembers acknowledged the long-term effort and collaboration behind the zoning changes and affordability commitments.
labels_to_summaries.C27:
• Council held a resolution for six weeks that would allow the city to partner with Pittsburgh Regional Transit on new steps being built around Downing Street in the 6th Ward

• The steps will connect Hancock Street to Herron Avenue via Downing Street

• Pittsburgh Regional Transit will provide access rights through their property so the city can maintain proper public walkways around the new stairway

• The agreement covers who will own, access, and maintain the steps after they're built - at no cost to the city

• The resolution is due back to the Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs Committee by May 14, 2025

• Pittsburgh Regional Transit is willing to grant these access rights for public benefit
labels_to_summaries.G27:
- Pittsburgh City Council voted to delay a decision on an agreement with Pittsburgh Regional Transit (PRT) for six weeks.
- The proposed agreement is for a new set of city steps being built on Downing Street in the 6th Ward.
- The new stairway will connect Hancock Street to Herron Avenue but needs to cross PRT property to give the public access.
- The agreement would settle who is responsible for the ownership, access, and maintenance of the steps after they are built.
- This arrangement is expected to come at no cost to the city.
labels_to_summaries.O27:
- The City Council deferred Resolution 2025-1589 for six weeks, delaying action until May 14, 2025.  
- The resolution would authorize the Mayor and the Director of Mobility and Infrastructure to enter a cooperation agreement with Pittsburgh Regional Transit.  
- The agreement covers ownership, access, and maintenance of new city-owned steps to be built around Downing Street in the 6th Ward.  
- The steps connect Hancock Street via Downing Street to Herron Avenue and require public access through Pittsburgh Regional Transit property.  
- Pittsburgh Regional Transit will grant access rights at no cost to the city.  
- The cooperation agreement aims to formalize responsibilities after construction is complete.
labels_to_summaries.C28:
• Council approved a $93,000 increase to the city's equipment leasing budget for the Office of Community Health and Safety to buy vehicles and equipment

• The money comes from the Stop the Violence Trust Fund and increases the total authorized spending with the Pittsburgh Equipment Leasing Authority to $7,999,319.37 for fiscal year 2025

• This amendment updates Resolution 21 of 2025, which originally set up cooperation agreements for city departments to purchase and lease vehicles, equipment, and professional services

• The resolution passed without discussion during the meeting

• The Equipment Leasing Authority handles vehicle and equipment purchases for all city departments through a centralized system
labels_to_summaries.G28:
- A City Council committee recommended adding $93,000 to the city’s 2025 equipment and vehicle budget.
- The additional funds are specifically for the Office of Community Health and Safety to purchase new vehicles and equipment.
- According to the legislation, the $93,000 will be paid for by the Stop the Violence Trust Fund.
- The increase brings the city's total equipment leasing budget for the year to $7,999,319.37.
- The committee’s affirmative recommendation passed without any discussion.
labels_to_summaries.O28:
- The City Council approved a $93,000 increase to the existing $7,906,319.37 budget for vehicle and equipment purchases.
- This raises the total authorized amount to $7,999,319.37 for the City of Pittsburgh Equipment Leasing Authority.
- The additional funds are specifically allocated to the Office of Community Health and Safety.
- The increase was part of an amendment to Resolution 21 of 2025, which covers leasing and purchasing vehicles, equipment, infrastructure, and professional services.
- The motion to approve the amendment passed unanimously with no discussion.
labels_to_summaries.C29:
• Council approved an amended agreement with Pittsburgh Water for the Haverhill Project, increasing the city's total reimbursement to $992,628.77

• The new amount represents a $382,513.30 increase from the original 2023 agreement (Resolution 404)

• Pittsburgh Water is managing the entire project, including:
  - Storm water management system design and construction
  - Road replacement and rehabilitation
  - Hiring design consultants, construction management, and contractors

• The project is funded through multiple sources:
  - $220,000 from grants
  - $772,628.77 from city bonds spanning 2015-2024

• The resolution received affirmative recommendation and passed without discussion

• The city will reimburse Pittsburgh Water for all project costs up to the approved limit
labels_to_summaries.G29:
- The City Council recommended approving an additional $382,513.30 for the Haverhill Project, bringing the city's total reimbursement for the work to $992,628.77.
- The project includes both roadway replacement and the design and construction of stormwater management systems.
- Pittsburgh Water is managing the project, and the city will reimburse the agency for the costs.
- The additional funding will come from city bond funds issued in various years (2015, 2017, 2023, and 2024).
- Council members passed the recommendation for the amended agreement without any discussion.
labels_to_summaries.O29:
- The City Council approved an amended reimbursement agreement with Pittsburgh Water for the Haverhill Project.  
- Pittsburgh Water is managing the design and construction of storm water management, roadway replacement, and rehabilitation.  
- The City will reimburse Pittsburgh Water up to $992,628.77, which is an increase of $382,513.30 from the previous agreement.  
- The increase covers costs for retaining a design consultant, construction management/inspection consultant, and construction contractor.  
- Funding sources include grants and bonds from various years, totaling the approved amount.  
- The motion to approve the agreement passed with no opposition.
labels_to_summaries.C30:
• City Council approved an "Agility Agreement" between Pittsburgh and the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT) that allows both agencies to share equipment and services without paying each other

• The agreement covers sharing items like crash vehicles, road repair equipment, and assistance with maintenance of roadways, bridges, signage, and lighting

• Instead of billing each other, the city and PennDOT will track what they borrow from one another through this system

• The agreement costs the city nothing and can last up to eight years

• Kim Lucas, director of the city's Department of Mobility and Infrastructure, explained that the city sometimes needs to borrow PennDOT's crash vehicles to protect work crews, while PennDOT sometimes needs similar help from the city

• The agreement received an affirmative recommendation from the committee
labels_to_summaries.G30:
- A City Council committee recommended approving a new "Agility Agreement" with the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT).
- The agreement allows the city and PennDOT to share services and equipment without having to pay each other.
- Instead of exchanging money, they will track the "in-kind" services they trade, such as repairs and maintenance for roads, bridges, and signs.
- For example, the city's Department of Mobility and Infrastructure (DOMI) could borrow a PennDOT crash vehicle to protect a work zone, and PennDOT could later ask for similar help from the city.
- The agreement will last for a term of up to eight years and has no direct financial cost to the city.
labels_to_summaries.O30:
- The City Council approved Resolution 2025-1659 authorizing the Mayor and the Director of the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure to enter into an Agility Agreement with the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT).  
- This agreement allows the City and PennDOT to exchange and document in-kind services such as roadway, bridge, signage, and lighting maintenance at no cost to the City.  
- The agreement will last up to eight years and helps track shared resources without financial transactions.  
- Director Kim Lucas explained the agreement covers situations like borrowing PennDOT’s crash vehicle to protect City work zones and providing assistance when direct payment is not possible.  
- The motion to approve the agreement carried with an affirmative recommendation from the Council.
